comments.commentBody: LaRussa unimpressive, using position players is no reward to Cardinal fans. And, running with Pujols at plate?! Cost him the game. We know the Mets can't hit, but the Cards need hitting.

I think that anyone who denies the Rockies talent will not know what hit them come October. The Rockies are serious contenders this year. They are a different team than the one in 2007. May I remind any Colorado-deniers of the outcome of the Rockies-Phillies outcome during the playoffs two years ago. Swept them in 4 games. Now you're thinking of the World Series outcome. That team is not the team it was either. Also, their own talent came back to bight them. Because of their quick playoffs, they lost all momentum in the long days leading up to the Series. I also think that Ubaldo Jimenez is A serious threat for the Cy Young. He throws 95-100 mph throughout the entire game, leaving hitters  devastated. The only threat for the West is the Giants, with a great home record and very solid pitching. Good luck to Manager Tracy and his 2010 Rockies!

Congrats to Jerry Manuel, who managed his pitching staff beautifully in this game. Kudos also to the pitchers, and to Cora, Reyes, and Castillo for their beautiful defense. LaRussa, on the other hand, managed like he didn't care if he won or lost. He mailed it in.

The Mets showed grit and determination when their bats were doing nothing. They hung in there and got a memorable win.
it looked like perez was ready to bat. you gotta love him at the plate.  that's baseball.

After 11 innings it didn't matter who won.
Real winner was the suspense and both teams kept it going.

Baseball needs "instant replay" to correct wrong calls.
Bad calls leave a bad taste and a feeling of robbed game.

I woke up pleasantly surprised that the mets won. I was expecting them to lose. This is a franchise that has a rich history of disappointing...but lets keep in mind, this is the third straitght strong outing by a Mets starting pitcher....

A few threads back was the discussion of games taking too long. . . . yeah, right.
How many things in today's World have no regard for the clock? If you can't appreciate that, I feel sorry for you.
Cute post, Andrew.

We stayet Maywood hotel April 2010 You could not find a better location for staying in Istanbul, it is very convenient for Hagia Sofya, Blue Mosque, Basilica Cistern, Grand Bazaar etc etc etc. The spice Bazaar is just 10 mins leisurely was tram stop is 2mins walk.The breakfast was lovely, lots of choice and once again the staff were very polite and helpful. Lovely fresh food served every morning!

The room was meticulously cleaned and re-stocked with tea/ coffee fresh linen and towels every day!

We stayed in one of the refurbished rooms with very nice furnishings and fittings. The ensuite bathroom was large with marble fixtures and a very large and powerful shower!
The staff at the MAYWOOD Hotel especially Mr.Burhan is very welcoming and go out of his way to assist you. He is very friendly and helpful;When we arrived the hotel Burhan were very hospitable offering us drinks and Turkish Delight. heis experts at recommending places to visit in Old Istanbul. his treat you more than a guest at their hotel; hismake you feel like family.All in all, we would definitely recommend MAYWOOD HOTEL ?STANBUL as a real value, with some luxurious amenities and wonderful staff, excellent location.Thank you for a wonderful stay!
Robert&Ann NJ

Sorry, editors, the public no longer takes a leap of faith when it reads the Times.  The NYT is about the only paper left that can lay claim to broad, deep and reliable reporting of public affairs.  Please don't squander that reputation with excessive and unnecessary use of anonymous sources.  Too often, it just sounds like a reporter's bias.
The Times lies; Fox News lies. No difference.

The Times claims "All The News Fit to Print", "The Paper Of Record".  The constant refrain of could have, should have, and all the other sundry excuses by editors has simply grown beyond the pale. And all the wordy excuses by the reporter(s) explaining the granting of anonymity just adds to my irritation.  The race to the bottom of newspaper journalism does not need another participant.  Mr. Hoyt need not call editors for explanations anymore.  The Times has become all too predictable.

we just got home from Istanbul, I was there with my boyfriend for 1week and we went to New Hatay Restaurant our first night, cuz we heard so much good things about it. They wasnt that pushy and noicy like the other places we passed by, and it looked beautiful from the outside.

The food was amazing, we went there for two nights and it didnt matter what we ordered, everything was really tasty! Everything, from the food to the drinks and the dessert.

And i really liked their tables on the outside, were you could sit a cold night and dont freeze cuz of the heaters. Lovely! And that they speak many different languages. inc Polish too)))

The atmosphere couldnt be more perfect, romantic and very friendly. And i like that the staff was really kind and professional and they took very good care of us, especially Erkan(ER?C). Thank you for being such a friendly person and lovely conversations! We will sure be back to visit next time we come to Istanbul.

I really do recomend HATAY Restaurant place to everyone!Can't wait to go again this year
Bjk NYC

Mr. Kristoff, as usual, is confusing issues. The reason women die in childbirth is the same reason men die from diseases--poverty and the complete lack of health care in countries such as Afghanistan and Niger.

Women are not dying from childbirth because they are considered unimportant or because the men will not allow them to go to a hospital. In fact the typical scene in a city hospital in a poor county is a woman in labor arriving for treatment carried by her male relatives who walked for endless miles in the bush carrying her on their shoulders.

The problem is that hospitals/clinics are hundreds of miles away from rural communities, and the lack of trained midwives.

I don't understand why Kristoff can never show men and women in poor countries as sympathetic to each other.

I think that priests should not be married because that would compromise their full commitment to the Church. Priests are supposed to be on call 24/7 and a wife and kids could change that. Instead of catering to the needs of the parish, they will need to take care of their family. Another factor in all of this a married priest's payment. He does have to support a family. This will strain the Church for cash.
Excellent column, and I am Catholic.

I attended the funeral today of a dear friend who died way too early. I cried during the service not just over the death of my friend, but also over the possible death of the church as I have known it. As I recited the prayers and listened to the music, I thought to myself, "Where else in the world can you experience beauty and history so woven together, hear of the timeless yearnings of human beings, experience mystery, and tap into that which, for want of a more specific word, we call the soul?"

Working with the needy is a very important part of the mission of the church, but its magnificence also lies in its rituals. Many religious people love liturgy not because it provides them with pie-in-the-sky myths that make life easier to take, but because the rituals, the words, the music give them the strength to face reality head on, to accept it, to love it, and to remain humble before it. I would rather the church be taken over by social workers than by people who claim to know the truth and judge others, but I also hope the magnificent rituals that tie us to the past and connect us to the future do not disappear,

Forty years ago, as a twenty year old social worker, I watched the good sisters of St. Vincents tackle a drunk angry gangrenous old man.  In a few minutes, they had him washed, dressed in clean clothes, and were working at cleaning the wounds on his feet.  I have never forgotten them.  They turned up their sleeves and went to work on a human being that most people would have abandoned.  Nothing beats nuns!

You have correctly discribed the two different churches. If only Vatikan would listen to you, these things would not happen. Moreover, denial or ignorance of what happened in the past is not a solution rather creates more solutions. The Pope is very ineffective and seems to have a denial and ignorance policy. The churches in South America, Africa should teach them how to bring respect and honesty to the church.

Good thinking!

Yikes.  Op-ed writers should study up a bit on theology & Catholic teachings before making such broad statements.  My Catholic friends would have little use for this piece.  It prescribes solutions from without (the Church should model itself on the world!) rather than from engaging the Church's problems from within, from a Catholic perspective.  The first has no hope of connecting with Catholics or the Church, the second is more helpful.  The problem with these public opinings about the Church and its problems is that they're written to make a point to an audience, not to engage in a cooperative search for a solution or for the truth.  (P.S., please don't treat non-canonical accounts of Jesus' life as equivalent to the canon.  There's a reason some books made it and others didn't.  Especially Gnostic texts.  That's (intellectually) offensive to *any* thinking Christian, not just Catholics.)

Yes, absolutely.  I grew up among vibrant, socially committed, fun-loving and visionary nuns who were very very cool.  Many of my most meaningful childhood experiences of liturgy were in services that these women led.  They were clearly resentful of the fact that they had to have a man present to sacralize the Eucharist -- "shut up and consecrate" was the attitude they seemed to have.  I have to say that it is largely because of them that I still consider myself a Catholic.  These early experiences were reinforced by the wonderfully reflective and soulful liturgies I participated in as a young researcher in the poor periphery of Sao Paulo, Brazil, expressing the commitment of the "Church of the People" to establish "the Kingdom of God on Earth," as an embodiment of the pursuit of justice and equality.  Faith in this sense is a spirited engagement of mystery AND questioning, not passive acceptance of dogma handed down an ossified patriarchal hierarchy.
Although the waiter and service was fine.Worst food we have ever eaten (or not eaten).How anyone can give this place any stars is a mystery. Maybe it is just a good bar ?

Nick, I am so glad that you wrote this column. I am a Catholic who married and raised my child outside the Catholic church, precisely because I rejected the Church's irrational, rigid, unhealthy doctrines on sexuality and gender. Nor did I want my child -- a boy, as it turns out -- to absorb the paternalism of the Church hierarchy.

Yet I have always had great admiration for the grassroots, progressive nuns, priests and lay workers who toil tirelessly, at home and abroad, on behalf of the neglected and poor. My first "charitable contribution" -- $1.67 -- was made, at age 9, to the Maryknoll sisters (my parents subscribed to their monthly magazine). Even now, I contribute monthly to my former parish in Manhattan, an upper-West Side institution, built in 1900 and staffed by Franciscans, that serves a trilingual population -- Dominican, Creole and English-speaking -- and has a choir and masses in each language (all 3 choirs sing at the Christmas Eve service). The Church also operates an elementary school, thrift shop, food kitchen, and senior center. It exemplifies in practice what Catholicism should be about. Moreover, I believe your story about the jeep-driving Maryknoll; one of the sisters at my Catholic elementary school used to hitch up her habit and run (she wore bobby socks) whenever a kid needed her in a hurry.

The Catholic patriarchy has taken some well-deserved blows recently, including from your colleague, the inestimable Maureen Dowd. The Church certainly needs more "Marys" (and "Maureens") and less old boys. Yet we who grew up Catholic, and have known outstanding priests and nuns, recognize that, Catholic doctrine aside, these individuals are true humanists and progressives, who serve people, not ideology. I'm glad that you've helped to set the record straight.

You make some good points about the need for the Church to serve all, and the neediest most of all.  But those who want to make a strong argument in support ordination of women ought to not focus on what Jesus did, because although He certainly had women in His circle, and treated women and men alike with love and respect, when He gave the invitations to the Last Supper at which He instituted the priesthood of His church, they went exclusively to the 12 men.

I wonder how many of the real Catholics think that this is a good idea.  Allowing public opinion to inform cardinal rule is a poor substitute to fixing the real problems that Vatican 2 has introduced.  The reformation of the church in the last century is a disgrace.

The "church" you admire is not the Catholic Church. What you admire is a collection of individuals who do wonderful things for other people. Those individuals do not need religion (or whatever it is that the Vatican is peddling) to do the good deeds they do. All they (and anyone else) needs is the will to sacrifice for other people. The Catholic Church is a sick relic from centuries past. It cannot fade into complete oblivion too soon.
